title: (x) Heinrich Böll Stiftung - (similar to) Gravur Condensed {Dav}
content:
Hi,

I am looking for the logo’s font of the »Heinrich Böll Stiftung«:

[http://www.boell.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20090614065525/http:/www.boell.de/ "http://www.boell.de")

Does anybody know this font? I thought it could be DIN or Mittelschrift but both typefaces don’t seem to match exactly.

Thank you in advance :-) ,

Oliver
author: olvradam

comments.content: looks a bit like ISOCTEUR. it comes with autodesk CAD-program, but i found it marked as a free font for download once.. (thats how i found it..). cant find it now, though.. sorry.

Now thats one nicely kerned logotype.. :)  
_( So, Why did they use a monospaced font for this.? )_

’ [Gravur Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20090614065525/http:/www.lineto.com/The+Fonts/Categories/Text+Fonts/Gravur+Condensed/)’, by Cornel Windlin, may be an alternate..

Dav, [formlos](http://web.archive.org/web/20090614065525/http:/www.formlos.net/)

Hi,

yes, the »Gravur Condensed« is a very good alternative: Thanks! I am agreeing with you that the kerning of the existing logo is really terrific. I did not design it but I am going to correct it :-)

Oliver

»Gravur Condensed« has rounded tips. The logo you link to does not have rounded endings.  
The logo font is much more like a »DIN 1451« or a variation thereof. In fact, it is not DIN, however, it is so close as to call it a variation of DIN.  
The upper bowl of the capital B is smaller on the logo. DIN’s capital B has identically sized bowls both upper and lower. Also, the endings on the capital S finish with a straight edge on the logo, whereas DIN’s capital S does not have such a feature.

More searching is needed.

For a DIN example of this company name, see:  
 [http://flickr.com/photos/luxuryluke/3081004809/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090614065525/http:/flickr.com/photos/luxuryluke/3081004809/ "http://flickr.com/photos/luxuryluke/3081004809/")
